review_blob:
12 oz. bottle
Aroma:Brown sugar sweet with caramel malts and spicy hops present in the background
Appearance:Clear dark brown with a decent head that could have lingered longer but laced nicely
Flavor:Caramel malts and brown sugar sweet nicely balanced by the hops that were present.  Alcohol was there but not overly so
Palate:Sweet at first with bitterness coming on and lingering at the roof of the mouth.  Nice
Overall:Another solid offering from what is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries

12 oz. bottle
Aroma:Smokey, sweet, burnt something...strange but not unpleasant
Appearance:Clear dark red amber with a quickly disippating head.
Flavor:Sour wine with malts and hops and alcohol and blending together to make something truly strange that I will admit I did not like all that much.
Palate:That strange taste cloyingly sticking to the roof of my mouth
Overall:  I appear to be in the minority on this one but I must say I did not really like this beer.  I appreciate its complexity because it was certainly that but it did just not go well with my palate.  I figure this is like how perfumes and colognes are meant to intermingle with your bodys natural oils to create the overall scent.  For some people this might work well but with my it kinda stank.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma:Chocolate and roasted malts prevalant with coffee underneath
Appearance:Classic dark brown with a disappointing head that dissipated quickly
Flavor:Here is where I was pleasantly surprised by the deep roasted malts with some sweet chocolate and bitter coffee very nicely balanced with the alcohol presence
Palate:Some bitter dryness here but the roasted flavors lingered well
Overall:Not phenomenal but certainly worth a peek.  I liked it and would drink it again.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma:Sweet malty scent with spicy hops underneath
Appearance:Hazy bronze with a smallish head that lingers and laces well nonetheless.  I normally dont do this but I am going to have to take a point here for the artwork on the label.  A quality beer like this deserves something a little more professional looking instead of like something I printed off my home PC.  Now if this was the look they were going for than bravo.
Flavor:Hoppy makes me happy nicely balanced with the sweet malts
Palate:Bitter hops linger quite well with alcohol present but not overbearing by any means
Overall:Better than I expected honestly.  I dont think it is worthy of the 4s I am seeing but still I did like this beer a lot and it would be great for session drinking.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma-Mild malt and hops scent.  More corn and alcohol than anything else.  Not much to speak of.
Appearance-Standard lager clear golden color with a quickly disappating head.
Flavor-Why reproduce mass production style lager with a higher alcohol content?  idk but if this is what you are after than more power to you.
Palate-Bitter alcohol with metallic tones.
Overall-If you want to get drunk quick and you like the taste of the mass produced lagers this is the beer for you.  It is not the beer for me however.

Usually I go into each category to explain the rating but the fact is is that beer does not exactly rate the time.  It was a watered down, fake raspberry tasting and smelling brew.  The color was clear amber with basically little to no head to speak of.  It was simply too over the top and too manufactured to give it the scent and the flavor.

12 oz. Bottle:
Aroma:  Yeasty and malty with undertones of spicy citrus.
Appearance: Hazy orange straw with a rocky head that lingers nicely with only minor lacing.
Flavor: Makes me feel like a monk.  Yeasty, bready, lightly bitter and dry.  There is a sweetness to it as well which makes for a wonderful balance.
Palate: The sweetness really comes out here first, yielding to a lingering dryness that stays with your mouth for a pleasant finish.
Overall:  Well done.  If you like your brews to remind of you living with monks on top of a mountain close to touching God then this is certainly close to being at "The End of the World".  A fine beer from Unibroue.

12 oz. bottle
Let me start by saying that I fine the brews from Dogfish Head to be truly solid if not excellent.  I love the fact that they are willing to be daring in their attempts.  I have not rated in a while which is a shame because I have been busy trying quite a few beers.  It just got the to point that rating was taking too much time.  Anyways here goes.
Aroma: Not as hoppy as I expected but it is present with a undercurrent of honey and the apricots.
Appearance: Clear, bright orange with a smallish lingering head.
Flavor: Here is where you get the hops.  It is bitter and dry and just underneath it you can taste the sweet fruitiness of the apricots.
Palate:  The bitterness lingers on your tongue for an exceptional amount of time.  Finishes somewhat dry but not overly so.
Overall: I could see drinking a lot of this beer and never knowing that apricots were part of the recipe.  It is quite tasty and enjoyable if you like a good bitter IPA, which I certainly do.  Another fine offering from Dogfish Head.

1 pt. 9.4 oz bottle
I see that my rating for this beer is skewed from the rest being given to it.  Let me start by saying that this was a nice package with a ceramic looking bottle and cork.  Normally something I would even give a point or two.  However it was clear that this particular did not ship well as the cork was only maybe half an inch into the bottle and it appeared as if some leakage had occurred.  After opening the bottle and pouring it was also clear some type of mold or fungus had begun to grow along the rim of the bottle and I had to fish a large chunk of it out of the glass.  Given all this I am not one to give up on a bottle that I paid decent money for.  There was practically no head and the beer was somewhat flat further proving to me that some leakage had taken place.  The only real flavor I can say came through is malt, malt, and more malt finishing with a dusty dry taste.  The one saving grace for this brew was that once I was done I gotten a nice little buzz.  Of course that may have been from the fungus or mold but a buzz is a buzz nonethless.  Maybe some day I can give this beer another shot but I will wait for a fresh shipment and a close inspection of the bottle to see if it is worth my time.  I must say that I find this beers scores odd as I read other reviews as it does not seem as many people liked it very much.  Why the somewhat high rating then is a mystery to me.  Peobably the beer snobs giving it a higher rating than it deserves because it comes from Belgium.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Sweet light malt and some vanilla.
Appearance: Amber in color with a nice off white head that sustained well.
Flavor: I did not read the deScription before I tasted it and even though the scent hinted at it I was quite surprised at the flavor.  At first I thought it was coriander I was tasting but after going back and getting the bottle I realized it was probably the vanilla and bourbon oak melding into this taste.  Even though it does not feel right as I feel there must some other spice added that is just difficult to identify.  Perhaps it is coriander or ginger.  I am simply unsure.  It was sweet but not unpleasantly so.  I also did not know when I first tasted it that it was an A-B product.
Palate: Very smooth and sweet.  Not as full bodied as I had expected in a bourbon cask ale.
Overall:  Beer snobs that we are we must begin to look past the brewer and the label.  This beer should be rated higher than it is.  I enjoyed it.  Even if it was sweet and medium bodied.  It was different but not unpleasant.  I grew up near Milwaukee but even though I cannot say I am a fan of Miller I have a fair amount of disdain for Anhueser-Busch.  Growing up where I did however gave me my appreciation for beer in general.  All that being said I would drink this beer again as it provides a nice change of pace your normal rotation.

Off tap at Blincos in Raleigh.
Very simply the best barley wine I have ever had hands-down.  It was as smooth as a babys bottom and if you did not know it was a barley wine this brew could get you in real trouble fast.  Be careful with this one!

Loved it!

Bottle
Aroma: Bitter chocolate, some sweet and malts.
Appearance: Mahogany with an off white head that did not sustain well long after the pour.
Flavor: Dark chocolate flavor.  Like dark chocolate it is bitter with some sweetness.  It was somewhat thin but interesting.  There were also some coffee and roasted malts flavors as well.
Palate:  Was bittersweet and dry which was to be expected with an 8.5% alcohol content.
Overall:  I see that I am giving this one of the highest ratings on the board so far.  I honestly think if you did not tell people this was from Michelob and just made them rate it based on its merits it would receive a higher rating in general.  Yes, we are all beer snobs.  Nonetheless this offering was quite potent.  Maybe hitting too many over the head with the dark chocolate.  It is certainly not subtle and it could be better balanced with a stonger hops offering.  Nonetheless I did enjoy this beer for what it was advertsied to be which was a chocolate beer.  It was certainly that.

P.S.- The bottle that this and the Vanilla Oak came in are unique in that they have a bullet shape.  After opening however you find it is just a plastic top covering a metal screw off cap like you would find on a 40 oz. malt liquor.  A cork here would have been much more appropriate.  Therefore the appearance score was deducted a point when it was more than possible it could have been a postive feature instead of a drawback.

I am not going to go through each categaory as I usually do in my ratings.  This is just simply one of my favorite brews year after year.  Its tasty and always makes me look forward to next year.  Its somwhat corny but I love how they change the scene in the background of the label each year too.  Its amber in color with a decent off white head and good balance of hops, malts, and a somewhat bitter bite.  Make sure this is in your rotation year after year.

12 oz bottle
Aroma- Sweet malty.  Smell reminded me of brown sugar with lightly floral undertones.  In no way do I mean hops when I write floral undertones.  Hops were pratically nonexistent on the nose.
Appearance- Deep, clear red brown.  Pretty.  Only a minor head at the beginning of the pour that did not sustain at all even though carbonation was OK while drinking.
Flavor- Surprisingly in the flavor I denoted some hoppiness up front with caramel malts present.  The mouthfeel was somewhat thinner than I expected.  The sweetness (sugar and raisins?) remained but was well overpowered by the bitter finish.
Palate- Bitter finish as stated above.  Lingered rather well which surprised me.
Overall- Not a terrible brew but not as good as say Samuel Smiths Winter Welcome.  You can see that they were really attempting to move in that direction but there is still some work to get that level.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Floral hops scent with honeysuckle and lilac tones.  Very pretty.
Appearance: Very slightly hazy golden with a minor white bubble head.  Head was disappointing.
Flavor: Tasty hops.  Not overpowering....just tasty.  Light malts and nutty toast underneath.  Very enjoyable.
Palate: Hops
Overall: Tasty IPA with a nice blend of floral hops.  One of the better IPAs I have had.  I enjoyed it very much.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma:I personally found this beer to have a sweet fruity peach scent with alcohol evident in the nose.
Appearance: Clear ruby red with a foamy rocky head.  Quite nice.
Flavor: Malty, with sweet fruits, and yet dry as well.
Palate: Back to the malty and dry
Overall: Not bad at all.  Interesting beer and enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Somewhat hoppy but not overly strong.  Some malt present as well.
Appearance: Best head of any of the other St. Georges I have had.  Darker than your average golden.  Mostly clear with decent carbonation.
Flavor: Hoppy but not overly so with some malt as well a little citrus.  Quite nice.
Palate: Finishes rather bitter as I would have expected an ale to.
Overall:  Not a bad beer by any stretch.  Quite enjoyable overall.

On tap from the Flying Saucer in Raleigh, NC
Aroma: Heavily scented with nutmeg, cinnamon, and coriander.  Sweet and light.
Appearance: Deep hazy amber orange in color with a decent head but it did not sustain or lace much.
Flavor: Nice solid pumpkin pie flavor.  Most of the reviews are not identifying coriander but I definitely smelled and tasted it. I believe they used it to help balance and define the flavor they wanted to achieve with this brew.  Or I could simply be wrong.
Palate: Finished sweet with nutmeg lingering on your tongue.
Overall: I enjoyed it quite much.  Great Fall brew.
beer_name: Carolina Beer Co. Cottonwood Pumpkin Spiced Ale

review_blob:
12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Chocolate and butterscotch.  Very sweet smelling with some roasted malts present.
Appearance: Almost opaque black in appearance.  When held up to the light you can actually see a tremendously pretty mahogany red.  Little head was the only drawback to the appearance of this brew.
Flavor: A solid porter with a nice balance of roasted and chocolate malts, hops, and carbonation.
Palate: Finishes somewhat dry but the roasted malts linger nicely on the roof of your mouth.
Overall: Well crafted porter that you can enjoy repeatedly.  Bravo!

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Malty scent with pumpkin, nutmeg, and cinnamon present
Appearance: Clear amber yellow with an OK head that did not last long but overall carbonation was on the high side
Flavor: I love pumpkin pie and this brew at least made me think of it but I would have liked to see a more aggressive flavoring and better balance
Palate: Finished spicy cinnamon and just a bit bitter
Overall: Not a bad brew for a change of pace and to get you in the season.  Not something you want to drink over and over again though.

12 oz. bottle 2006 version
Aroma: Very malty nose with sugars and alcohol beneath
Appearance: Muddy red brown with a nice head of medium sized tan bubbles and minor lacing
Flavor: Caramel and chocolate malts are pronounced with an alcohol bite
Palate: Malty and dry.  The best thing about this beer though is it is not as dry as you would expect with a 13.25% content.  I did a double take when I read it on the label as I expected an elevated number but not that high!
Overall: Well done on a finely crafted brew.  I enjoyed it much and would like to try it again.  I find it very interesting that some people are saying it was clear red when the one I had was very murky which others have stated too.

11.2 oz. bottle
Aroma: Nose is sweet with pear, citrus, and a bit of coriander, yeast, and hops in that order of strength.
Appearance: Hazy pale orange with serious thinning at the edges and a practically nonexistent head that did not develop even after aggresively pursuing one.  I will upgrade based on head traits but I do not usually downgrade.  This one however was one of the worst I have ever seen.
Flavor: Starts sweet with the orange peel evident and ends almost sour with the coriander coming through.
Palate: Thin mouthfeel with that corander sour taste lingering.
Overall: I did not love this beer by any stretch but I cannot say it was not worth trying.  If by the artwork on the label they are implying this is Mothers Milk than mother needs to go into a treatment program because her milk was awfully sour.

Tap at Carolina Ale House at Brier Creek in Durham, NC
Aroma: Lots of hops with a light hint of caramel malts and pepper underneath.
Appearance: Light amber yellow with little head.
Flavor: Tasted hoppy like it smelled but not quite the right balance or sharpness to make it special.
Palate: Bitter, dry finish.
Overall: Not a terrible bear but not a great one either.  A nice change of pace beer but not something I would make a session out of.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2006

1 Pint 9.4 oz. bottle
Aroma: Fruity with apples, pears, and banana with caramel malts.  Very sweet.  Some alcohol in the nose.
Appearance: Very pretty deep mahagony color with a fantastic, sustaining head of large and medium bubbles that laced nicely.
Flavor: Starts sweet and malty.  Full bodied.  Ending slightly bitter and spicy but balanced so very pleasant.
Palate: Slightly bitter and dry makes the mouth tingle pleasantly.
Overall: I very much enjoyed this beer.  I was afraid I would be in for a much larger alcohol wallop given it is a 9% brew but it was well balanced.  Bravo

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Lots of caramel and chocolate malts.  Some nuts and dark fruit in the nose as well.
Appearance: Deep dark brown with thinning at the edges.  Strange sediment, like cocoa powder.  Virtually no headto speak of.  This is clearly the weakest category for this brew.
Flavor: Again very malty, with some cohocalate and toffee.
Palate: Medium-bodied with a bittersweet finish with the taste of the malts lingering in the mouth.
Overall: Not a bad beer.  Not a great beer.  You could really like this beer if you love the taste of malts.  I was most disappointed by the appearance however and the taste was enjoyable but not enough for me to rate higher.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Caramel malts and light hops.
Appearance: Very pretty, mostly clear amber red.  Not much of a head to speak of.  What was did not linger long except at the edges.  Lost a point due to the head.
Flavor: Malty with only a hint of sweet and hops.  Fairly thin mouthfeel with decent carbonation.
Palate: Pretty smooth with only a touch of mailty bitter which I would expect from a brown ale.
Overall: Not bad, not great.  Another beer made for the masses but definitely on the upper quarter of that distribution market.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Watery, faint hops.
Appearance: Pale yellow.  Slightly hazy.  Very little head that did not sustain.  Rather disappointing.
Flavor: Watery, thin, yet smooth.
Palate: Lightly bitter and dry over time.
Overall: I will be honest.  I was disappointed with this beer.  I had real high hopes and that was before I looked on the site and saw how highly rated this brewery is.  Not surprising to me however was that this was the lowest rated of their brews.  What does surprise me is the large number of retired brews they have that are rated quite high and yet this is the offering that they decide to distribute to the mass market.  Why must the mass market brew be so boring???

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Nice and hoppy like you want from an IPA with sweet citrus coming through nicely.
Appearance: Slightly murky dark orange which was quite pretty with an excellent rocky foamy head that laced and lingered very well.
Flavor: Lots of hops with a pop of orange peel that gave it nice balance.  Quite tasty.
Palate: Finished like it tasted and slightly dry like you would expect with a beer of this high alcohol content.
Overall: A quality IPA that I would be willing to enjoy again and again.

Aroma: Watery with a hint of yeast, malts, and hops.
Appearance: Pale yellow with a decent lasting head of medium to large bubbles.
Flavor: Of all the Miller brews this one is the only one that has a hint of sweetness against its bitter taste with a just a hint of hoppiness.
Palate: Bitter alcohol.
Overall: I prefer Miller beers over Bud and Coors and when in comparison against other mass marlet brews of this variety it is not terrible.  In comparison against a truly well-crafted it is awful at best.  However, often due to availability at sporting events and dive bars you could do a lot worse than selecting this beer.

Aroma: Thin, corn, and just a smidgen of hops.
Appearance: Pale yellow in color with a head that has large bubbles that sustain all ight during the drink most of the time.
Flavor: Thin watery with a hint of malt of hops.
Palate: Thin and bitter with a metallic finish.
Overall: The basic light beer.  Not much to speak of but there are worse on the market.

Aroma: Watery, very thin malt and hops.
Appearance: Clear yellow.  When poured from a tap has a very frothy head that lingers incredibly well.  Not so much when poured from a bottle.
Flavor: Thin and bitter.
Palate: Moslty bitter and a little dry.  Just a hint of hops.
Overall:  Your average mass market beer.  Not much to speak of and yet I have had much worse.  Given its obvious availability it is consumed in great quanitities but it is not as thin as most light beers and slightly more bitter than the middle-of-the-road.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Chocolate and caramel matly aroma.  Nutty.  Not overly strong in scent.
Appearance: Dark amber.  Darker than the overage Oktoberfest.    Tan head really lasts.  Bonus for the head.
Flavor: Malty and caramel and surprisingly a bit bittersweet.
Palate: Bittersweet is the only way I can really describe this.  Different.
Overall: Tough one to rate but I did enjoy it.  Would love to see what this one tastes like out of a tap.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Smokey caramel malty odor is pleasant.
Appearance: Clear amber with a decent head that lingered fairly well during the drink.
Flavor: Malty with caramel and spices.
Palate: Medium bodied and not overly dry.
Overall: Not a bad beer.  Enjoy during the Fall season.  Gotta love Oktoberfests.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: I was a bit stuffed up during this tasting so the scent was difficult for me to accurately determine.  What did come through was yeasty, wheat with fruity banana and apple with a nice hop scent.
Appearance: Hazy golden orange with small to medium bodied sediment floating throughout the beer.  For some this might be a turnoff but for me it just makes it interesting.  The head was a bright white in color that sustained somewhat throughout the glass.
Flavor: Quite yummy sweet yeast with the fruits again coming through nicely balanced with the hops.
Palate: Fnished nicely with a medium body and some bite along the roof of my mouth.  Not bitter or overly sweet either.  Balance is an important theme with this brew.
Overall: A truly quality Belgium Tripel.  This is one that you can use as a standard bearer for the style.

12 oz. bottle Arcobrau (no mention of Waltrose anywhere on the bottle) Bavarian Dark Wheat Beer
Aroma: Mostly wheat and dark malty with minor hops undertones
Appearance: Color is dark murky orange brown.  Head is nice with almost white bubbles that sustain very nice during the glass.
Flavor: Like the aroma is mosly wheat and some alcohol
Palate: Finishes bittersweet (more bitter than sweet than sweet is present)
Overall: I liked this brew and could see drinking it with some regularity.  Could definitely go well with pretzels and a football game.

12 oz. bottle for Patriot Collection
Aroma: Strong scent of sarsparilla, licorice, and vanilla.
Appearance: Cloudy dark brown with some floating sediment I was surprised to see.  Head was off-white and not very substantial.
Flavor: Powerful sarsparilla and licorice which blended into a root beer type flavor I guess.  It was odd though.  I love root beer.  Sarsparilla on the other hand I am not as fond of.  They used the black licorice to alter the taste towards root beer but the molasses was not quite sweet enough in the initial taste to get it there.  Weird.  Cant say I really enjoyed it but definitely some points for originality and effort.
Palate: Finished cloying sarsparilla with some sweet.
Overall: This is a tough one to rate.  On one hand it was very unique.  On the other I really did not like it very much.  It was hard to finish the bottle.

12 oz. bottle from Patriot Collection
Aroma: Very soft hint at the chocolate malts, sweetness, and touch of hops.
Appearance: Very cloudy dark mahogany is accurate as described.  No sediment present in this unfiltered beer.  Head of just off-white bubbles was not substantial but what there was did linger and lace well.
Flavor: Here the malted rye is noticeable at first giving way to sweet roasted nutty malts.
Palate: Finish was tart.  Mouthfeel was clean and made the roof of my mouth tingle.  Complex and long finish although not very heavy bodied.
Overall: I must say I liked it overall.  I would have liked it to have a stronger nose and more impressive head (especially after reading the label deScription).  Some are giving this low appearance marks due its muddy coloring but I have no issue with that.  Again I liked it and would drink it again.
beer_name: Samuel Adams James Madison Dark Wheat Ale

review_blob:
12 oz. bottle from Patriot Collection
Aroma: Smokey burnt chocolate malts and milk chocolate.
Appearance: Deep dark black with some small-bodied sediment that rather surprised me.  Head was excellent as it had nice small off-white bubbles that sustained and laced very nicely.  Bravo!
Flavor: Roasted malts are most prevelant.  Caramel is underneath with just a hint of red fruits.
Palate: Finishes somewhat bitter as the chocolate malts erode and the alcohol presents.
Overall: Very nicely done.  To be honest I was somewhat surprised at just how well done this beer was coming from a mass market brewer.  I also really liked the Ginger beer in this collection so now I am anxiously anticipating the other two.  I hope to be surprised again as I am unfortunately biased to be expecting not to enjoy these other two as much given how much I liked the two I have tried so far.  Time will tell.....

12 oz. bottle from Patriot Collection
Aroma: Heavy ginger covers honey. lemon, and bread tones
Appearance: Cloudy amber honey in color with a white bubble head that disappointingly did not sustain very well.
Flavor: Ginger, lemon.  And let me just state for the record....I really like the taste of ginger.  I mean I could a plate of plain ginger if it was put in front of me.  So take this rating with that in mind.
Palate: Finished clean with the ginger taste lingering nicely on the roof of my mouth
Overall: Again, I love ginger so this is not really fair and this rating should be taken with that preference in context.  I liked this beer a lot and could see drinking a whole lot more.  It would be awesome paired with Oriental food.
beer_name: Samuel Adams Traditional Ginger Honey Ale

review_blob:
12 oz. bottle from Summer Pack
Aroma: Lightly fragrant sweet floral scent.  Best part of the beer.
Appearance: Pale golden in color with the typical uninspiring, quickly dissipating head.
Flavor: Grainy and bitter.
Palate: Finishes bitter and somewhat metallic
Overall: The least favorite of the Summer variety six pack I sampled.  Like the other of their brews it is clearly made to appeal to the masses and is not terrible but just not very special either.

12 oz. bottle from Summer pack
Aroma: Smell is very nice when first poured with lots of lemon and coriander.  Scent does diminish over time.
Appearance: Clear, dark, gold in color with the same boring lame head that all Saranacs that I have sampled have.
Flavor: Tastes like it smells with sweet citrus.
Palate: Finishes quickly.  Very sweet.  Not bitter at all.
Overall: In the top half of Saranacs beers.  I enjoyed this one.  I just wish they would do something to improve that lousy head that each and every one of their seems to own.  Its funny to me too how every one of their bottles has a label around the neck showing this pint poured with a nice one inch head.  Maybe on tap it is significantly improved but in the bottle I would challenge anyone to be able to generate that kind of head short of shaking the hell out of the bottle prior to opening.  Again though, let me clear, this was a nice beer.

12 oz. bottle from Summer pack
Aroma: Lightly sweet and yeasty with some citrus beneath.
Appearance:  Hazy light amber in color with the disappointing I have come to expect from this brewer.
Flavor: Thin mouthfeel with the yeast flavor you would expect from a Hefe but this is a really boring version with essentially no complexity.  Obviously an attempt to appeal to the masses.  Not terrible but just not that great either.
Palate: Finishes thin and quickly with the yeast and a hint of banana.
Overall: If you have read any of my other ratings on Saranac you already probably know how I feel.  Too much mass appeal without enough effort to make something truly identifiable or unique.  Of the Saranac brews I have tried it is in the upper half.

2005  Drank 8/2/06
Aroma:  Nice scent of sugary molasses, alcohol, with a hint a vanilla and dark woods.
Appearance: Hazy amber brown with a decent head of off white bubbles, but not as nice a head as I usally prefer.  Screw off cap and shrunk wrap bottle were a little less than top notch and had me worried about the contents.
Flavor: Poweful alchohol (at 10% I would expect no less really) with some malty sweetness, caramel, and vanilla.  There was an unpleasant metallic taste that effected the other flavors.
Palate: Dry as I would expect but not as dry as it could be.  Finished fairly quickly.  Left a sweet taste over time.
Overall: I had a hard time placing what this beer reminded me of but I think it somewhat resembles Anchor Steam.  Although in saying that I will also say I much prefer Anchor Steam to this brew.  There was the metallic flavor that damaged my enjoyment of this brew but after I rated it and saw a 3 I realized it was right where it needed to be.

12 oz bottle
Aroma-Wheat and yeast with a light finish of floral hops.
Appearance-Amber gold with relatively disappointing head.  This head issue is typical of all Saranac beers I have sampled.
Flavor-This is not a bad offering overall from Saranac.  This would be my second favorite beer from this brewery but if you look at the ratings that is not really saying all that much.
Palate-Finishes grainy and hints at sweet and lemon.  Not awful but not great.
Overall-I could having a session with this beer.  Especially if I am with a group of people that are used to mass market brew.  Its OK but far from special.

12 oz. bottle from Beers of Summer collection  Note: Label is brown not red and BERRY is not in the name.  However, based on the deScription this is the same beer.
Aroma: Sweet and malty with a hint of berry
Appearance:Slightly reddish amber brown.  Head again is a major disappointment as usual with the Saranac offerering.  Just does not sustain and is weak from the get go.
Flavor: This is the best of the 6 beers from Saranac I have tasted.  Unfortunately that is just not saying very much.  It is rather thin but it does have a nice sweetness to it that I liked.
Palate: Finishes fairly quickly and clean.
Overall: As stated this is the best of the Saranac beers sampled.  Clearly a company too focused on trying to appeal to the masses instead of working on staying true to the style that they are attempting to produce.  Of all of their beers though I could actually see drinking a few of these.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma-Yeasty with a touch of coriander.
Appearance-Looked like a hazy orange soda.  Head was disappointing large bubbles with very little sustainment and virtually no lacing.  This is one of the most common knocks I have on Saranac beers.
Flavor-Some wheat and coriander but overall weak in overall taste for a white.
Palate-Finishes quickly and slightly dry.
Overall-An OK beer at best but nothing special.  I am quickly coming to the conslusion that Saranac is a small beer company with a big beer mentality.  In other words, by attempting to appeal to the masses they have made a range of beers that is overall rather boring and tend to taste a lot alike regardless of style.

1 Pt. 6 oz. bottle
Aroma: Sweet orange peel scent with only a hint of hops.  Smelled somewhat like an orange popscicle.
Appearance: Hazy orange, like Tang.  Thin around the edges.  Virtually no head to speak of which was disappointing.
Flavor: Wheat and lots of spice overpowered by mushroomy,  chalky, and dusty flavors.
Palate: Dry somewhat metallic finish with some licorice
Overall: I was tremendously disappointed with this beer as I was looking to Averys version of a Golden Belgian Ale.  Perhaps the travel and the storage of this beer altered its flavors and it just did not age well in the bottle.  I cannot imagine this being a popular choice if this is its regular flavor.  Reading other reviews I have to believe it is not.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Dark malts with sweet red fruits.
Appearance: Nice, clear deep reddish amber.  Head was minimal however.
Flavor: Unique.  Sweet and malty.  The raisin taste was noticeable.
Palate: Finish began sweet and ended up dry red wine.  Mouthfeel was medium heavy.
Overall: Very interesting beer and yet I cannot rate it as highly as some of the other raters here as I just did not really love the flavor even though I can appreciate it.  Worth checking out regardless.  This company definitely makes some quality brews.

750 mL bottle Batch #29
Aroma: Yeasty and wheaty odor wih a hint of citrus.  You definitely knew you were going to be drinking a White beer with this scent.
Appearance: Hazy straw orange in color.  Not as much sedimenation as I expected with the pouring instructions on the label but that was fine.  Head was frothy and rocky white bubbles with some lacing that sustained nicely.
Flavor: Yeasty and wheaty like the odor suggested with the orange peel coming through at the end.  The coriander was very subtly  noted which blended together gave it a bit of a bubble gum taste.
Palate: Thin mouthfeel that did not linger overly long but the different flavors coming through after swallowing was pleasant.
Overall: Quality beer again from Allagash which is a brewery I am growing more fond of with each sampling.
